entry.title: Linkage of debit memo to original sales order
entry.content:
Dear all,

i have a hopefully short question: Assuming there was a sales process via sales order 1 to Customer A. The invoice and billing document have been created and the the materials have been shipped. 

Now you need to create a debit memo because the material price increased and you need to charge it further to the customer A. So you create a debit memo with reference to the origin invoice which is related to sales order 1 . Again, billing document and accounting documents have been created. BUT: There is no linkage between Sales Order 1 and the debit memo as far as i can see. Indeed through the relationship browser you see, that there is a relation but the value flow is not linked. So i cant find a fiori or report where i see the debit memo which increases the margin to the sales order. 

I cannot add the sales order manually while creating the debit memo. The only think i can think of is to extend profitability segment with sales order and sales order item which will be entered manually. 

Any thoughts from anyone would be helpful! 

 

Thank you!

entry.title: Re: Service Contract number missing in billing document (...
entry.content:
Good day @DavidBirrer 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Manage Solution Orders, Output Management

Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) for Sales Billing, Maintain Form Templates

In summary, in public cloud edition, the billing document inherits the Solution Order reference by standard, but the Service Contract number is not automatically passed to the invoice output or XML payload. This has become a common requirement in public cloud, especially when Solutions Orders generate Service Contracts that are later billed together with other items. (e.g., subscriptions for service orders).

My advice is to extend your invoice form, or you use BAdI SD_BIL_OUTPUT_DATA_MODIFY to expose the Service Contract number in the XML output. You don’t require any configuration in Solution Order or billing control beyond this.

Below is a clean-core step-by-step options to Expose the Service Contract Number:

Search “Maintain Form Templates”

The example below references a different custom version. In your form SD_BIL_INV should be copied to a custom version.

Ensure you add Service Contract Number and map it from the billing item data. In the Data Source, include Reference Document or Service Contract Number. à Then Bind this field to the XML output context or PDF layout where needed. à Then activate and assign the new form in Output Parameter Determination.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Accelerating Service Excellence: AI-Powered Supplier Booking in SAP Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
In service operations, every minute counts. When a customer’s equipment breaks down, the speed at which parts or services can be procured often decides the overall service experience. Traditionally, finding and booking a supplier is a time-consuming, manual process — switching across systems, endless searches, and delayed approvals.

With SAP Service Cloud V2, we’ve turned this challenge into an opportunity:
👉Enabling service agents to search, select, and book suppliers directly from the service order screen — backed by real-time integration, AI recommendations, and automated purchase requisition creation in S/4HANA.

Why This Matters

  • Faster service delivery – Agents don’t waste time on manual supplier lookups.
  • Smarter decisions – AI recommends the best supplier based on availability, cost, and past performance.
  • Seamless integration – Purchase requisitions are automatically created in S/4HANA, ensuring compliance.
  • Better customer experience – Faster parts procurement = quicker issue resolution.

How It Works

When customers raise a Case followed by creation of service order by an agent  , speed and accuracy are everything. Delays in finding the right supplier or creating purchase requisitions can slow down resolution and impact customer satisfaction.

🔹Step 1: Supplier Search in Service Order

Agents open a Service Order in Service Cloud V2 and access a supplier search panel built with SAP Build Apps.

SAP Build APPs:

 

 

 

 

This the destination where we call SAP S4HANA Suppliers using SAP CAPM

 

🔹Step 2: Fetch Supplier Data from S/4HANA

The system makes an API call to S/4HANA to fetch available suppliers with details such as pricing, lead time, and rating.

🔹Step 3: AI Recommendation with RAG

We use Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) to analyze supplier data and recommend the most suitable supplier for the request.

🔹Step 4: Supplier Selection & Purchase Requisition

Once the supplier is confirmed, a Purchase Requisition is instantly created in S/4HANA via API — no manual intervention needed.

🔹Step 5: Persistence & Metadata with CAP

All supplier interactions, recommendations, and decision logs are stored via SAP CAP, ensuring traceability and audit readiness.

 

This will create a purchase order in S4HANA public cloud 

 

Solution Architecture

  • SAP Service Cloud V2 – Service order management
  • SAP Build Apps – UI for supplier search & booking
  • S/4HANA APIs – Fetch suppliers + post purchase requisition
  • AI with RAG – Intelligent supplier recommendations
  • SAP CAP – Database layer for persistence & metadata

 

 

End-to-End Flow

  1. Agent opens service order in Service Cloud V2.
  2. Supplier search triggered via Build Apps UI.
  3. Supplier data fetched from S/4HANA APIs.
  4. RAG model recommends best supplier.
  5. Agent confirms → Purchase Requisition created in S/4HANA.
  6. Metadata stored in CAP for reporting and audit.

Business Impact

✔️80% reduction in supplier booking effort
✔️Improved procurement compliance with auto-PR creation
✔️AI-driven supplier choice → faster and smarter decisions
✔️Unified service experience – all from within Service Cloud V2

Closing Thoughts

This solution is a perfect example of how SAP’s ecosystem (Service Cloud V2, Build Apps, S/4HANA, CAP, and AI) can work together to simplify complex business processes.

By embedding supplier booking directly into the service order workflow, we’ve not only accelerated service execution but also paved the way for intelligent, AI-powered procurement in the future.

entry.title: AI-Powered Self-Service API in SAP ITSM Adapter: Transforming SAP Support
entry.content:
Introduction

In today’s digital-first business landscape, organizations expect fast, accurate, and autonomous support. SAP has introduced an innovative capability that addresses this expectation — the AI-powered Self-Service API within the SAP Cloud ALM ITSM Adapter.

This new functionality enables AI-driven, automated assistance that provides customers with immediate solutions through SAP Notes, Knowledge Base Articles (KBAs), and other SAP documentation, often resolving issues before a support ticket is even created.

What Is the SAP ITSM Adapter API?

The SAP Cloud ALM ITSM Adapter API serves as an integration bridge between SAP Cloud ALM and external IT Service Management (ITSM) systems such as ServiceNow,.

It provides REST-based interfaces that allow organizations to:

    • Create and manage SAP support cases directly from their ITSM systems.

    • Synchronize  master data (s-users/landscape information data) between customer ITSM and SAP Support Backbone

    • Connect seamlessly to the SAP Support Backbone for consistent case handling and tracking.

This integration ensures that SAP and customer support teams operate within a unified process and shared visibility.

What’s New: AI-Driven Self-Service API

The Self-Service API enhances this integration by embedding Artificial Intelligence (AI) directly into the SAP support flow.

Instead of always creating a new SAP case, the system now uses AI and natural language processing to analyze issue details and propose immediate recommendations — powered by SAP’s extensive support knowledge base.

Key Features

  • AI-Powered Analysis
    The API interprets user inputs such as issue descriptions, system IDs, and error codes to understand the context.
  • Automated Knowledge Recommendations
    The AI engine searches SAP’s knowledge repositories and suggests SAP Notes, KBAs, or support documentation relevant to the problem.
  • Instant Self-Service Resolution
    Users can review recommendations and apply fixes immediately — often resolving the issue without needing SAP engineer intervention.
  • Continuous Learning
    The system continuously learns from resolved cases to refine and improve future recommendations.
  • Seamless Integration
    The API can be embedded into customer-facing portals, chatbots, or ITSM UIs, creating a unified and intelligent self-service experience.

Business Benefits

  • Faster Issue Resolution
    Customers receive instant, AI-generated recommendations — reducing downtime and eliminating unnecessary ticket creation.
  • Reduced Support Overhead
    By resolving repetitive or known issues automatically, the API helps reduce manual workload for IT teams.
  • Improved End-User Experience
    Users get 24/7 self-service support, faster responses, and higher satisfaction.
  • Data-Driven Insights
    Organizations gain visibility into common issue types, self-service success rates, and potential knowledge base improvements.

 

Example Workflow: AI-Driven SAP Case Creation with Self-Service

The following diagram illustrates how the AI-powered Self-Service API integrates with a customer’s ITSM system to streamline SAP case creation.

Figure 1: ITSM Integration – SAP Case Creation with Self-Service (API-based)

Step-by-Step Process

Internal Ticket Created
A user raises a support ticket in the customer’s ITSM system (e.g., ServiceNow or Jira).

  1. SAP Case Candidate Generated
    The system determines SAP support may be required and creates a SAP Case Candidate with relevant details such as subject, system, component, and S-User contact.
  2. Send Case Candidate to SAP Cloud ALM
    The ITSM system sends a partial or full payload through the SAP ITSM Adapter API.
  3. AI Generates Self-Service Content
    SAP Cloud ALM uses AI Support Services to analyze the ticket data and produce self-service content, including:
    - SAP Note or KBA recommendations
    - Component suggestions
    - Other contextual solutions
  4. Customer Reviews Self-Service Recommendations
    The recommendations are displayed within the ITSM interface.
    - If helpful, the user applies the solution and the issue is resolved automatically.
    - If not, the system proceeds to create a full SAP support case.
  5. SAP Case Creation (Full Payload)
    The ITSM system sends the complete case data to SAP Cloud ALM, which then creates a formal SAP case in the SAP Support Backbone.
  6. Case Resolution and Synchronization
    All updates and resolutions are synchronized between the customer ITSM and SAP, ensuring transparency and consistent status tracking.

AI-Driven Self-Service API, in action

Request Example

Here’s an example of how to use the SAP ITSM Adapter API endpoint /supportcases/recommendations/solutions in a self-service scenario to retrieve recommended solutions (e.g., SAP Notes or KBAs) based on a case description.

Endpoint

POST /supportcases/recommendations/solutions

This endpoint analyzes the problem description and returns the 10 most relevant solution documents. this result can be filtered by:

  • type, 
  • component
  • product
  • category
  • age

Request Body

{
  "description": "Security Code Scan on Results - vulnerability [CRLF injection/HTTP response splitting(Web Server)-Portal]"
}

Additional parameters may be provided to increase the accuracy of the result

Request answer

{

"count": 10,
"totalCount": 10,
"results": [
{

"id": "1475602",
"title": "Identifying and resolving security vulnerabilities in SAP Business Objects products [How-To]",
"summary": "A third-party tool such as WebInspect or AppScan has been pointed at a deployment of a SAP Business Objects product (BI 4.x/20xx- 4.1, 4.2 , 4.3, 2025 ) and the resulting report shows a number of security vulnerabilities (such as Cross Site Scripting",
"type": "KBA",
"component": "BI-BIP-SEC",
"product": "",
"category": "How To",
"recommended": false,
"age": "Released 4 months ago",
"url": "https://me.sap.com/notes/1475602",
"rank": 1

},.................

}

Implementation Tips

  • Integrate the Self-Service API into your existing ITSM interface or self-service portal for a unified user experience.
  • Use conversational AI or chatbots to collect issue descriptions and trigger the API.
  • Continuously update and validate your SAP Notes and KBA usage to maximize resolution accuracy.
  • Monitor key performance indicators (KPIs) such as self-service success rate, case deflection rate, and average time to resolution.
  • Ensure secure authentication (OAuth/SAML) and proper data governance across your IT landscape.

Looking Ahead

The introduction of the Self-Service API marks a step toward proactive, AI-driven support in SAP environments.

Future enhancements may include:

  • Conversational AI integration for natural language support.
  • Generative AI summarization of complex SAP Notes and KBAs.

Conclusion

The AI-powered Self-Service API within the SAP ITSM Adapter brings intelligence, speed, and automation to SAP support.

By leveraging AI insights, SAP Notes, and KBAs, customers can resolve many issues independently — improving efficiency, reducing downtime, and optimizing the overall support experience.

This innovation not only enhances integration between customer ITSM systems and SAP Cloud ALM but also paves the way for a smarter, more proactive support model for SAP customers worldwide.

Learn More

SAP Cloud ALM – ITSM Adapter API Overview (api.sap.com)

SAP Cloud ALM APIs Documentation (help.sap.com)

SAP Community: SAP Cloud ALM and ITSM Integration Blogs

entry.title: Overview of Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Posting Rules can be used for processing bank statement items. A posting rule determines exactly how a bank statement item is posted. It determines which accounts are posted to on debit and credit sides, and also whether or not the respective debit or credit side is cleared. Amongst other things, a posting rule can consist of a posting area, a debit/credit account symbol, a posting type and an on-account posting key.

They tell the system which G/L accounts to debit and credit, depending on the transaction type.

For example:
When a customer payment is received → Debit the Bank Account, Credit the Customer Account.
When bank charges are posted → Debit Bank Charges Expense, Credit Bank Account.

These rules ensure that every business transaction results in correct and consistent accounting entries without manual intervention.

Where Posting Rules Are Used

Posting rules are mainly used in:

  • Bank Account Management / Cash Management(Apps like Manage Bank Statement Rules, Manage Automatic Payments, Manage Posting Rules, etc.)
  • Payment Processing
    (e.g., in scope items like J58 – Bank Account Management )
  • Incoming and Outgoing Bank Statement Processing
    (via Manage Bank Statement Monitor or Reprocess Bank Statement Items apps)

How Posting Rules Work

Each posting rule defines:

  • Posting Area (e.g., subledger, G/L)
  • Debit/Credit Indicators
  • G/L Accounts to be used
  • Posting Keys
  • Document Type

For example:
When you process an incoming bank statement, a posting rule determines:

  • Which account should be debited (e.g., Bank Clearing Account)
  • Which account should be credited (e.g., Customer Receivables)

To understand what exactly a particular posting rule does (which accounts are posted and cleared), have a look at the table under Overview of the Posting Rules.

Viewing or Modifying Posting Rules

In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, configuration is managed via SAP-delivered content.
Therefore Posting rules are usually predefined by SAP and cannot be modified.

Examples of relevant SSCUIs (depending on your scope items and country version):

  • 102386 – Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements
  • 102387 – Assign Accounts to Posting Rules

How to View or Configure Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Unlike the on-premise system, where you use transaction codes (like OT83, OT74, etc.),
in the Public Cloud version, posting rules are managed via configuration activities (SSCUI) in the Manage Your Solution or CBC (Central Business Configuration) tool.

Step-by-Step: Viewing Posting Rules

Step 1: Access Configuration

  1. Go to the SAP Fiori Launchpad.
  2. Open the app Manage Your Solution (or Configure Your Solution in new systems).
  3. Choose Configure Your Solution tile.

Step 2: Find the SSCUI for Posting Rules

  1. In the search bar, enter:
    "Bank Statement" or "Posting Rules"
  2. Look for the following configuration activities (SSCUI IDs may vary slightly by country):
    102386 – Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements
    102387 – Assign Accounts to Posting Rules
    102385 – Define Posting Keys and Posting Types

Step 3: Open the Configuration Step

  1. Click Open Activity.
  2. In Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements (102386), you can view all pre-delivered posting rules.
  3. Each posting rule shows posting area, posting type, debit/credit indicator, and document type.
  4. These rules are SAP-delivered and cannot be changed directly in Public Cloud to maintain integrity.

Step 4: Assign G/L Accounts

  1. Open Assign Accounts to Posting Rules (102387).
  2. Here you can see which G/L accounts are assigned to each posting rule and account symbol.
  3. You may adapt account assignments if your scope item allows (depending on business role and configuration permission).

Step 5: Test the Posting Rule

  1. Go to the app Manage Bank Statement Monitor or Reprocess Bank Statement Items.
  2. Upload or simulate a bank statement.
  3. The system automatically applies the posting rule based on the external transaction code or mapping configuration.
  4. You can then check the accounting document to verify which accounts were posted (via Display Journal Entries).

Modifying Posting Rules (Limitations in Public Cloud)

In Public Cloud, you cannot create or freely modify posting rules as in On-Premise or Private Cloud due to SAP’s standardization policy.

You can:

  • View and extend posting rules using SSCUI.
  • Assign or change G/L accounts linked to existing posting rules.
  • Create additional bank statement rules (via Manage Bank Statement Rules app) that determine which posting rule applies under certain conditions.

You cannot:

  • Add new posting areas.
  • Define entirely new posting rules or posting types beyond what SAP delivers.

Relevant Scope Items (Pre-Delivered Configurations)

Scope Item Description
J58Bank Account Management
J77Automatic Payments
J78Cash Operations
BD9

Bank Statement Processing

These scope items collectively handle posting rule configuration and bank integration.

entry.title: Re: ECC delivery qty not reduced when applying process co...
entry.content:
Note 2332231 - EWM split deliveries with zero quantity not updated in the ERP original delivery

Basically the system only updates the ECC delivery quantities after all the items in the EWM delivery is completed, meaning the ODO should be in the Completed status. Partially reduce the quantity to 0 is not possible without custom BADI logic.

entry.title: Re: Table KNVI ( Customer Master Tax Indicator ) generati...
entry.content:
One check you can do is go to CDHDR / CDPOS tables and see which user id showing for the extra entries in table KNVI. Some systems have background jobs (e.g., Customer Master Data Enhancer, Address Completer) that automatically enrich or supplement customer data after replication. These may create KNVI entries for missing combinations (e.g., sales org/distribution channel/division) based on default logic.

If you're using SAP MDG, DRF, or PI/PO, check if there are post-processing steps or enhancements in the replication framework that manipulate KNVI after initial sync.

entry.title: Reducing the DataBase Size of SAP ERP Systems Using Shell Copy Scenario
entry.content:
If your SAP ERP system has been running for an extended period, your database has probably grown several terabytes in size. This presents a double challenge: managing such a large volume of data is complex, and transitioning to SAP S/4HANA can lead to significant downtime. 

To unlock the digital transformation capabilities of the SAP Business Transformation Center (for more information, see [Everything about using SAP Business Transformation center for SDT S/4 HANA Conversion 2023 from ECC]), your target system needs to be manually prepared, as explained in [Creating the Shell System for SAP Business Transformation Center: A Practical Approach].  

If these challenges sound familiar, you’re in the right place! 

With Support Package 45 (SP45) of Software Provisioning Manager 1.0, a new scenario called "Shell Copy” is now available. Similar to the traditional “System Copy” process - where you use Software Provisioning Manager to copy or migrate an existing SAP ABAP system, the Shell Copy assists in system copying, but with one key difference: it significantly reduces the volume of your new target database. 

The Shell Copy scenario keeps the skeleton of your system, along with all your custom configurations and developments, such as cross-client customizing, dictionary, and repository data, while leaving out the application data (see item 1 in the diagram below). 

If needed, after performing a shell copy, you can use remote client copy (using the SAP_UCSV profile) for all clients except 000 (see item 2 in the diagram below).   A remote client copy for client 000 is not required as this is delivered during the Shell Copy process.

 

 

 

In numbers, the SAP tables DD002L, DD003L, REPOSRC, and SEOCLASS, which are part of the SAP system and contain important metadata, remain the same in both the source system and the target system. However, another table, AFPO, which contains application-specific data, is truncated: 

Source: ￼                                                                         Target: 

When we tested the Shell Copy scenario on our own small production system, we saw a significant drop in the volume size of the database: 

 Source:                                                                                                         Target: 

 

We expect that the reduction ratio will vary a lot based on how much application data your SAP system contains. At the time of the blog post, the Shell Copy scenario is only available through the product provisioning functionality for ‘EHP8 of SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP’: 

 

The Shell Copy scenario is a homogeneous process, which means it works with the same type of database on both the source and target systems. It supports SAP Adaptive Server Enterprise (ASE), Oracle, MS SQL Server, and IBM Db2 for Linux, UNIX and Windows.  

Another key difference from the traditional System Copy is that Shell Copy uses a more advanced migration tool called the Database Migration Option (DMO) in Software Update Manager (SUM) 2.0, instead of the old migration monitor. 

Thanks to the features of SUM DMO, the Shell Copy process is not only more efficient, but also reduces the overall downtime. For example, the export takes place online with a manageable number of R3load jobs, so you don’t have to shut down the running SAP system during the Shell Copy process.  To ensure smooth operation of the productive processes, we recommend that you schedule the export in times of reduced workload.

entry.title: Re: Why can't MIRO provisional invoice conditions be edited?
entry.content:
Why Conditions are greyed out in MIRO is because, Provisional/Differential Invoice (Type '8') is designed for adjustments, not for altering pricing logic. SAP restricts condition editing here to maintain consistency with the original PO and GR. 3rd Party Spot Purchase Orders often lack GR-based invoice verification, which limits flexibility in MIRO. Conditions are copied from the PO and locked for editing to prevent discrepancies between PO and invoice values.

Some workarounds are

If business process allows, use standard invoice type (1) instead of provisional (8). This may allow condition editing depending on PO setup.

You can implement custom logic to enable condition editing by enhancing the MIRO screen behavior. This requires ABAP development and careful testing to avoid inconsistencies.

Ensure that the PO type allows for invoice verification with editable conditions. Some custom PO types may have restrictions hardcoded or via user exits.

I recently went through the blog post series you shared, and I wanted to thank you for putting it together. It provided a clear overview of the foundational concepts of BDC, its extensibility, and how customers can build their own data products. I truly appreciate the effort behind it.

As an architect with a strong functional and process-oriented background, I’m not deeply technical. I would be grateful for your support in helping me understand BDC from a functional perspective. If you could share any resources or links that explain BDC in a way that’s accessible to someone with my background, it would be immensely helpful.

Thank you in advance for your guidance and support.

Warm regards,
Anand TATIYA

entry.title: Slow performance with SQL Anywhere 17 build# 7908 and 8038
entry.content:
Our customers are experiencing very slow performance with SQL Anywhere 17 build# 7908 after upgrading from #6933. The new SQL-Anywhere driver seems to have some sort of "optimization", in that with every regular SQL-Query to retrieve data, it will run a significant number auf additional sql queries, mainly running through all the tables and counting all entries in every table before returning the requested dataset to the application. This reduces performance significantly. For example retrieving a recordset with #6933 runs for about 5-10 seconds, with #7908 it will take over 1,5 minutes.

Does this sound familiar to anyone?

We also tried downgrading our customers, but were not succussful. Customer usually run an unload and load tables optimization: if they do so the tables created in 7908 will trigger errors when being loaded with 6933. Does anyone know any trick here, how to unload tables and load them in the lower version again? Has anyone successfully done that?

Any help much appreciated,

mpp

entry.title: Please vote the influence request created for enhancing the Calibration Activity Domain
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We started using Calibration for last 5 years and the reporting is not working for us. 

Our process is to create multiple level of sessions and the subjects will be on these sessions. For ex: we initially create sessions at either Manager or Sr. Manager level and rate the subjects. After those discussions with Sr. Manager, we create sessions at group level and finally at the company level.

When we create group level sessions and tag the subjects, the ratings from the prior sessions are copied into this group level. But when we run reports on Calibration Activity, these ratings will not show until the session is finalized in the Audit Trail.

This is causing an issue with the reporting as we could not utilize the reporting as we need. 

I am requesting SF to enhance the reporting tool by tracking the ratings on the new session even if there is no change on them. I raised the below enhancement/influence request. Please review and vote for it so that we can make the product more usable and more flexible.

Request to track Ratings from the source in the Calibration Audit Activity 

Appreciate your help by voting this influence request.

Best Regards,
Balaji

entry.title: UX and application development with AI at ASUG Tech Connect 2025 a companion event to SAP TechEd
entry.content:
This year, SAP TechEd has several options to allow you to learn about the latest SAP technologies and how to apply them to your organization. In addition to TechEd in Berlin and the virtual option, there are “SAP TechEd On Tour” events in Louisville, Sydney, and Bangalore. In this post, I’ll share the sessions on application development and user experience that we are presenting at ASUG Tech Connect in Louisville, Kentucky. As you would expect many have AI -assisted capabilities to make both business users and developers more productive.

 

At ASUG Tech Connect, we have both lectures and hands-on workshops.

Lectures are a chance to hear from SAP experts and have your questions answered in the room.

Extensibility with ABAP Cloud and AI in SAP Cloud ERP (Jens Weiler)

Explore on-stack key user and developer tools in the ABAP Cloud development model, now enhanced with generative AI. Extend standard apps and manage custom ones in SAP Cloud ERP and explore transactional, analytical, and integration use cases like the extensibility AI assistant, queries for analytical SAP Fiori apps, and SQL services.
Tuesday, November 4, 2025, 11:15 AM-12:05 PM

What’s Next: AI-First Innovations in SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Suite (Ullas Holla, Peter Spielvogel)

Get a fast-paced look at how SAP is embedding AI and delivering cross-suite innovations that break down silos and speed up decision-making. We’ll cover the latest highlights from releases of SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Suite—plus give you a sneak peek at what’s coming in 2026 and beyond.

It demonstrates how to define a data source and expose it via a CDS view, enabling consumption through SAP Fiori elements, Eclipse ADT, and Postman. A live demo illustrates the creation of a simple SAPUI5 application that consumes the same OData service and is deployed to the SAP Fiori Launchpad, showcasing full-stack integration from backend data modeling to frontend delivery.
Wednesday, November 5, 2025, 8:00 AM-9:30 AM

Using Generative AI to Accelerate SAP Fiori App Development (Ullas Holla)

AI changes everything, especially for developing business applications. See how SAP’s latest coding agents let you build SAP Fiori elements apps using a conversational interface. Create apps using Joule, including a CAP service, sample data, and SAPUI5 customizations.
Wednesday, November 5, 2025, 4:10 PM-5:00 PM

Creating Better User Experiences with AI-Powered SAP Fiori Apps (Peter Spielvogel)

Discover how the latest AI features in SAP Fiori apps enhance user productivity and streamline onboarding. Starting with My Home and diving into commonly used SAP Fiori apps, see how AI simplifies information access, supports informed business decisions, and fosters seamless collaboration. Explore how conversational interactions are making SAP more intuitive than ever.
Thursday, November 6, 2025, 4:15 PM-5:05 PM

Hands-on workshops give you the opportunity to test the latest SAP innovations and gain access to the same tools and technologies we use to build apps for SAP S/4HANA.

Hands-on Lab: Get Started with ABAP Cloud for Classic ABAP Developers

Familiar with classic ABAP development? Explore how similar development works with ABAP Cloud using the ABAP RESTful application programming model. Use ABAP Cloud to build cloud-ready business apps, services, and extensions that follow clean core principles by default—on SAP Business Technology Platform and in any edition of SAP S/4HANA.
Tuesday, November 4, 2025, 1:10 PM-3:10 PM

Hands-on Lab: Explore Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities

Learn how to develop transactional applications using the ABAP RESTful application model in ABAP Cloud while leveraging Joule capabilities for ABAP developers.
Wednesday, November 5, 2025, 8:00 AM-10:00 AM

Hands-on Lab: Build On-Stack Extensions with ABAP Cloud in SAP Cloud ERP

Discover how to build extensions, applications, and services with the ABAP Cloud development model, using the ABAP RESTful application programming model and generative AI. You can explore how to extend standard SAP applications, consume public SAP APIs, and build new apps and services from scratch while getting practical insights through exercises
Wednesday, November 5, 2025, 1:00 PM-3:00 PM

Practice clean core extensibility in SAP Cloud ERP Private. Learn how to govern clean core development using the ABAP test cockpit, and how to use the ABAP Cloud development model and clean core extensibility principles to modernize your custom on-stack extensions.
Thursday, November 6, 2025, 1:00 PM-3:00 PM

For PO output, from the existing layout, against each value, list out the related table and field names. For example, vendor address would be fetched from LIFNR & ADRC. entry.title: Re: How to migrate service purchase order data by migrati...
entry.content:
Hello @Lily16 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Service Order with External Service Procurement, Procurement Integration, Migration Cockpit, API for Purchase Order

To summarise, the standard Migration Cockpit templates for Purchase Orders currently do not support account assignment category “R” in public cloud. The reason is because, the Service Document and Service Item Number fields are not part of the delivered migration structure for the “Migrate Purchase Orders” object.

The SAP Clean-Core approach recommends the following options:

  • Option A is to create Purchase Order Automatically from Service Orders (recommended by SAP)
  • Option B is to manually create post-migration: this is if you really need to migrate legacy POs for reporting.
  • Option C suggest a technical migration, where you use the side-by-side API approach. This should be considered if you need to preserve bulk historical data.

Below is step-by-step guide on how to achieve the goal:

First, search “Migrate Your Data” App

The screenshot uses the “Product Master Data” as a reference. In your case, choose the “Purchase Orders”

In your case locate the Purchase Orders --> Click Download Template

Open file --> scroll through to confirm that columns such as Sales Order, Sales Item, etc., exist but no “Service Document” or “Service Order Item” column is present.

Go to Manage Service Orders --> External Procurement Type =Yes --> Manage Purchase Orders -->AcctAssCat = R and the linked Service Order Number.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: People Intelligence for SuccessFactors – What It Is and Why It Matters
entry.content:
For those of us who have lived through Workforce Analytics (WFA), Report Stories, SAP BW, and countless Excel dashboards, this is more than a product update. It is the start of a structural shift - away from isolated HR reporting toward an integrated, AI-driven foundation for decision making.

At Pentos, we’ve been preparing for this shift since the first announcement. After a decade of helping clients around the world make sense of their HR data, we see People Intelligence not just as a new tool - but as the new operating model for people analytics.

From Workforce Analytics to Business Data Cloud

WFA has served many organizations well. It provided a structured model and a curated metric catalogue. But it lived in a different era: one where data warehouses were static, integration meant batch loads, and analytics meant explaining what happened last quarter.

People Intelligence is built on a different architecture. At its core lies SAP Business Data Cloud- a unified platform that brings together HR, Finance, Supply Chain, Spend, and external data into one governed space. Within this space, data products like Workforce Composition, Compensation, and Skills Insights are harmonized, semantically aligned, and ready for use.

The implications are profound. We’re no longer moving data into HR-only silos; HR data becomes a first-class citizen in the enterprise data landscape. Finance and HR metrics can live side by side. Attrition patterns can be analysed alongside cost or productivity trends. In other words, HR finally speaks the same analytical language as the rest of the business.

Why this matters now

For years, HR teams have struggled with three fundamental barriers: data fragmentation, manual processes, and limited ability to predict. People Intelligence addresses all three.

  1. Unified data foundation – By harmonizing data in BDC, organizations eliminate the classic “one truth for HR, another for Finance” issue.
  2. AI-powered insights – Embedded Joule, SAP’s conversational copilot, enables users to explore data through natural language. It’s not just “show me headcount,” but “how did turnover in critical roles impact delivery times?”
  3. Scenario simulation – With integrated data and modeling, leaders can test hypotheses: what if we shift hiring from one region to another? or what is the cost of a 5 % attrition increase in R&D?

These capabilities elevate HR analytics from descriptive to strategic - bridging the gap between insight and decision.

Joule and the promise of human-AI collaboration

AI has been a buzzword for years, but Joule represents a tangible step forward. Within People Intelligence, Joule serves as a co-pilot: it interprets questions in plain language, accesses governed data products, and provides contextual answers.

Think of a manager preparing a workforce plan. Instead of navigating through a maze of dashboards, they can ask Joule: “Show me attrition risk for engineers in Germany over the past year, and simulate the effect of a 10 % compensation increase.” The system returns not only a chart but also narrative explanations and recommended actions. This is analytics in dialogue, not static reporting.

Why SAP is making this move

SAP’s strategic direction is clear. Business Data Cloud is the backbone for all analytical applications (Lines Of Business) - Finance, Supply Chain, Customer, and of course also People. The company knows that analytics is only powerful when the underlying data foundation is consistent. This is intergral to the SAP Business Suite Strategy.

For HR specifically, this evolution also reflects market pressure. I know that many companies have turned to external tools such as Power BI, Visier, Tableau, ChruncHR, or OneModel because WFA’s closed structure limited flexibility. People Intelligence re-centers analytics inside the SAP ecosystem by offering the same openness those tools promise - without losing governance or integration depth.

The cornerstones of the solution

From SAP’s documentation and early partner experiences, three design principles define People Intelligence:

  1. Data Products over data models – modular, standardized, and versioned for re-use.
  2. Cross-domain integration – enabling HR to link directly with cost, revenue, and operational data.
  3. AI and simulation – moving from reporting the past to predicting and shaping the future.

These are not incremental improvements; they redefine what an HR analytics platform can be.

Are we limited in the data sets and metrics

People Intelligence is by design linked to SAP SuccessFactors. There are metrics covering the entire hire to retire lifecycle, starting with core HR, talent acquisition and talent management. Backed by powerful analytics and tailored insights, People Intelligence offers an holistic approach, with data from all sources – including external data – to understanding your organization, by delivering high-quality, harmonized data, this solution enables impactful workforce planning and seamless collaboration across your business.

  • Workforce Composition Insights: Understand the composition of your workforce and assess internal mobility trends.
  • Compensation Insights: Ensure fair and competitive pay structures across your organization.
  • Skills Insights: Identify existing skill strengths to pinpoint critical gaps and suggest potential development strategies and opportunities.
  • Succession Insights: Gain insights into succession planning to drive business continuity and talent growth.
  • Career Development Planning Insights: Get insights into development goals and skills linked to building a future-ready workforce.
  • Performance Insights: Leverage performance insights to drive productivity and engagement.
  • Goals Insights: Use goals insights to align with organizational objectives.
  • Recruiting Insights: Gain recruiting insights to attract and hire top talent efficiently.
  • Learning Insights: Utilize learning insights to offer effective training and development programs.

 

All metrics are provided out of the box by SAP and can be extended with additional customer-specific metrics and data sets from other domains, such as finance, customer and logistics.

This all means you get the core metrics covered as well as optional talent modules, depending on the landscape your organization has implemented. And the best part, of for some reason you have non-SAP modules implemented, you can create metrics covering those systems and blend with the metrics you have in your People Intelligence solution.

Preparing for transition

No end-of-life for WFA has been announced yet, but the strategic direction is unmistakable. Migration won’t happen overnight. Data governance, metric mapping, and enablement will take time.

Why early movers will benefit most

Those who begin the journey now will have the advantage of aligning HR data with enterprise data governance from day one. They’ll also be first to apply machine learning and AI exploration across domains.

And perhaps most importantly: People Intelligence provides a foundation for skills-based organizations. Its integration with the Talent Intelligence Hub means you can link skills, roles, and learning to business outcomes - finally quantifying the real value of talent.

Looking ahead

This article is the first in a two-part series. In Part 2 – Implementation Considerations, I go into the “how”: deployment models, integration patterns, and how to turn standard metrics into competitive advantage.

What matters now is understanding the why. People Intelligence is not simply the next version of WFA; it’s the architectural shift that lets HR operate on the same analytical backbone as Finance and Operations. It represents an (overdue) unification of data, technology, and business strategy - a space where analytics is no longer an afterthought, but an enabler of decisions.

If your organization is considering how to move from WFA or how to get started with Business Data Cloud, feel free to reach out to me to  explore how to make your HR data work smarter - today and for the future.

entry.title: How to Find and Process, in SapforMe , Cases created from a ByD or C4C Version 1 tenant
entry.content:
If in C4C or ByD built in support is not accessible , it is possible to fully process a case directly from SAPfor Me.

  • Login  to the support portal https://support.sap.com/en/index.html or access SAPforMe directly  : https://me.sap.com/home
  • Ensure you are accessing the portal with a  S user that belong to the correct account which should be the account containing the C4C or ByD installation. Your user must have  Case management access, read and write.

If you are unsure which S user to use, or whether you had the necessary access rights,  please check with our Customer interraction center

Our non technical hotline can be used, 24/7 for all  case access issues, case management, escalation request, call back, S-User management, etc.  more info : https://support.sap.com/en/contact-us.html?anchorId=section_42886245

  • Once logged to SAPforMe you can check if the S users is correct. Only a S user that belongs to the same installation and account as your tenant will let you manage your cases.

 

  • Navigate to “service & Support” to access all opened cases

  • Open “view” cases

If you case was opened from the legacy built in support in C4C or ByD, you will likely not be the person assigned to the case, you can easily find all tenant relevant cases  with the filter option.  The New C4C V1 Built In Support will always display the correct user.

  • If you case is still in progress, status should be anything except for “confirmed”, “ not sent to SAP” and “automatically confirmed”

You can further filter using the “system” field which is your tenant ID.

  • To find your tenant ID, open your tenant, go to the Work Center “Service Control Center” -> “system”.

From this view all tenant under your account will be visible

  • Copy the tenant ID in the filter field  of SAPforMe and it will display only the cases created from these tenants.

  • You can then edit your case and resume processing. For any support regarding case management, please contact CIC.
  • If you are not the reporter of the case you can add yourself as new contact in order to receive all case related notification

If you mark  one or multiple case as favorite , they will be displayed  on your SAPforMe Home page and you will be able to access them without searching again

 

Conclusion
With SAP for Me, managing ByD and C4C cases becomes simpler and more consistent , even when built-in support isn’t accessible. By following these steps, you can easily locate, filter, and process your cases directly from SAP for Me without interruptions. This unified experience ensures you stay connected to SAP Support, benefit from real-time synchronization, and keep all your customer interactions in one place.

entry.title: Re: How to move or delete a task from a Transport Request?
entry.content:
Dear Customer, 

 

Yes, using Export Customizing Transports app it is possible to move a task to another customizing Transport Request if the task is on "Modifiable" status. In other words, if the task was not released yet. 

In this case, the task needs to be assigned to your user. If it's not assigned, you can select the task and click on "Assign to me" button.

Once it is assigned to you, the "Move" button will be available. You only need to select the task and click on "Move". A pop-up will appear for you to choose the TR that you want to send the task. You can only send the task to TRs that are assigned to you. Therefore, in the value help, only the TRs assigned to you will be visible. If you want to send the task to a specific TR that is not assigned to you, you need to assign your user to it first by selecting the TR and clicking on "Assign to me". 

The TR also needs to be of type customizing and have the status "Modifiable". 

 

You can also delete a task by assigning it to your name and clicking on "Delete" button when selecting the task. 

 

For more questions regarding Export Customizing Transports app you might want to check KBA 3547695 - Export Customizing Transports - Frequently Asked Questions - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

 

Kind regards,

SAP Support.

entry.title: Drive more business outcomes out of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition – A Recommendation Guide
entry.content:
After spending almost 10 years helping customers activate and operate SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, I wanted to provide a quick guide on some initiatives based on my experience that you can follow to get more business outcomes out of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This blog will cover some of the top recommendations but is by no means a conclusive or complete list, as there are many other topics that can be added. Now, some of these recommendations may already be included in your subscription or some might not; this will be an individual customer situation, so I encourage you to contact your SAP Customer Success Manager, SAP Account Executive, or SAP Partner to inquire about your individual situation.

First, if you are reading this blog, it is because you have probably been operating SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for some time and are looking to get more out of your subscription investment.

If you are reading this blog and you are planning to implement public cloud, I suggest you read this first.

Let me provide you with some of my highlights:

 

  • New Innovations – Find and explore new innovations using the Release Assessment and Scope Dependency for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (SAP RASD - A valid Customer S-user ID is required for login) to analyze new innovations included in your subscription.  I have recommended this tool in previous blogs to get ready for upgrades so you can consume new innovation and maintain your system. However, in this case I want to focus on the topic of innovation only. The tool will highlight all innovations included in a release, or you can see the innovations tailored to your productive system usage. However you want to do this, I advise you to benefit from all this new innovation that was added to your system.

New Innovations - Release Assessment and Scope Dependency for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

 

  • SAP Business Artificial Intelligence – The SAP RASD Tool can also support exploring the special use cases for SAP Business AI (SAP Joule, Agents, embedded AI). You can use the tool to showcase what has been added into the release. Similar to the above use case, the SAP RASD tool can showcase all the topics per release or tailor them to your productive usage for SAP Business AI.

SAP Business AI - Release Assessment and Scope Dependency for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Another tool that can help you visualize the overall use cases for SAP Business AI is the SAP Discovery Center (https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/index.html), which you can use to explore what is delivered as standard so you can use it to assess your business needs. The difference with the SAP RASD Tool is that SAP Discovery Center presents all available cases independent of release for all SAP product portfolios and can also be tailored by SAP product (e.g., SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors, etc.), while in the case of SAP RASD, it shows the information by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and by release (e.g., 2508).

SAP Business AI - SAP Discovery Center

I have written on the topic of foundational elements for Business AI before, so I advise you to review this blog that contains many more recommendations on this important subject: Foundational Elements for Harnessing the Power of Business AI in Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Ed.

 

  • Manage News Application – The Manage News Fiori application in My Home for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition empowers system administrators to deliver timely, targeted updates directly to business users through a centralized news feed. By tailoring communication to organizational needs, the application enhances visibility and keeps users informed of key system and company developments—all in a single, easily accessible location.

Manage News Application

News - My Home

 

  • Keep informed of the latest regulatory changes: If you have multi-country operations and footprint, I recommend using the SAP Regulatory Change Manager to always stay up to date with changes in regulations. More information can be found here.

SAP Regulatory Change Manager

 

  • 3 System Landscape – If you are running a two-system landscape, you might want to work with SAP so they can convert you to the latest and greatest 3 System Landscape. The 3 System Landscape comes with additional benefits that will help you drive much more business value out of your SAP investment. To learn more about this topic, I recommend this blog and video that explain the process and benefits.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - 3 System Landscape

 

  • Parallel Line: If you are on a 3-System landscape and are not using the parallel line, you are missing out. The parallel line will provide you with an additional environment you can use to run testing, training, mock-up loads, test new configuration, try the configuration localization toolkit, etc. The parallel line can be used to avoid impacts to the main line and current business operations.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Parallel Line

I have also written about this topic in detail in the past, so feel free to look at this blog with all details:  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, three-system landscape, parallel line – High Level Introduction.

 

  • 2-Tier ERP Strategy – Maybe you implemented SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for some subsidiaries or maybe for your corporate business; however, the goal was, we are seeing more and more SAP customers running hybrid deployments to connect their SAP systems with either corporate headquarters running in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or looking at SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to bring new acquisitions or subsidiaries.

2-Tier ERP

The strategies are diverse and depend on your business requirements; however, SAP has many options to support you in this using our 2-tier models. I suggest you read this blog to learn more about these specific strategies: Exploring Deployment Models for Acquisitions Using SAP S/4HANA Exploring Deployment Models for Acquisitions Using SAP S/4HANA.

 

  • Extending to the new SAP Business Suite Packages - In February 2025, SAP announced the new SAP Business Suite. The Business Suite serves as a transformation engine, helping customers generate rapid cycles of innovation and continuous improvement as a service. This enables organizations to deliver greater business value and achieve improved outcomes through end-to-end processes. So with the new SAP Business Suite, you have a great opportunity to complement your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with some of the current packages (e.g., SAP Strategic Procurement, SAP Core HR (which includes SuccessFactors for example), SAP CX, etc.), or potentially change your entire subscription to the new SAP Finance and SAP Supply Chain Packages to benefit from more entitlements that cover more functionality to address specific business pain points. This last point is not available yet, but is planned for 2026, so stay tuned. But a new installation and subscription can start with new SAP Business Suite Packages right away.

SAP Business Suite

This strategy could prepare you for future consumption models where you have much more capabilities at your disposal. I invite you to learn more about this topic here: Unpacking the new SAP Business Suite.

 

  • WalkMe – WalkMe can help you with the onboarding of new users (e.g., if you are bringing a new company code or new country rollout) as it helps drive user adoption using its capabilities to ease the use of the system by providing guided tours, samples, and even automations of tasks. At the moment, WalkMe provides out-of-the-box content for MyHome, Procurement Specialist, Sales Representative, and Financial Accountant, and more content will be added in the future. You can also use its current editor capabilities to create your own content and help drive user adoption and onboarding.

WalkMe & SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

  • SAP Signavio Process Intelligence is a good option to really understand how the system is being used and try to drive enhancements based on current system usage and KPIs. Currently, SAP Signavio Process Intelligence offers two out-of-the-box processes including Order to Cash and Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management (EPPM) that can be used to drive inferences on these end-to-end processes. More end-to-end processes will be added in the future. However, customers can use Process Mining to create their own content to analyze their specific usage and drive enhancements to the overall system productivity and usage based on very concrete production data to help drive transformation of processes.

SAP Signavio Process Intelligence & SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

If you want to know more about SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and SAP Signavio Process Intelligence, check this blog and example.

 

I hope this selective list of recommendations provides you some ideas for your new projects, new business rollouts, or new business requirements. Feel free to discuss these points with your SAP Customer Success Manager, SAP Account Executive, or SAP Partner.

Your insights and opinions are valuable, so please don't hesitate to contribute by commenting on this blog.

Follow us via @SAP and #S4HANA or follow @Marco_Valencia (SAP Business Suite Customer Success Management).

entry.title: Integrações com APIs via SPROXY no Cenário ABAP/PI: Um Guia Prático para Desenvolvedores SAP
entry.content:
Olá, galera da comunidade SAP da Bahia! Como curador dessa comunidade vibrante aqui no Nordeste, eu sempre fico animado em compartilhar conhecimentos que facilitam o dia a dia de vocês. Hoje, vou falar sobre um tema que é pão com manteiga para quem trabalha com integrações em ambientes SAP: as integrações com APIs usando a transação SPROXY, especialmente no contexto ABAP/PI. Já fiz algumas em projetos para conectar sistemas legados com serviços externos, e acho que pode ajudar muita gente por aí.

Vou explicar passo a passo, de forma descomplicada, como se estivéssemos batendo um papo no café da firma (quem me conhece sabe que não gosto de café, mas serve o papo rsrs). No final, convido vocês a comentarem suas experiências – quem sabe não rola um meetup virtual sobre isso?

O que é SPROXY e por que usá-lo em ABAP/PI?

SPROXY é uma transação SAP que permite gerar proxies ABAP a partir de definições de serviços web, como WSDLs ou APIs RESTful. No cenário de Process Integration (PI), que evoluiu para o SAP Process Orchestration (PO), ela é essencial para criar interfaces que consumam ou exponham APIs de forma segura e eficiente.

Imagine que você precisa integrar o seu ERP SAP com uma API externa, tipo um serviço de pagamento ou um CRM nuvem. Em vez de codar tudo do zero, o SPROXY gera classes ABAP prontas para uso, lidando com autenticações, mapeamentos e erros. É uma mão na roda para evitar bugs e acelerar o desenvolvimento.


Passo a Passo: Configurando uma Integração via SPROXY

Vamos ao que interessa – o hands-on. Assumindo que você tem acesso a um ambiente ABAP/PI, siga esses passos. Eu testei isso em projetos reais, e sempre funciona bem com um pouco de paciência.

  1. Acessar a Transação SPROXY: Entre no SAP GUI e digite SPROXY na barra de comandos. Isso abre o Proxy Generation Tool. Selecione "Create Proxy" e informe a URL do WSDL da API que você quer integrar. (Dica: certifique-se de que o WSDL está acessível via HTTPS para evitar problemas de segurança.)

  2. Gerar o Proxy ABAP: O sistema analisa o WSDL e gera classes ABAP automaticamente. Você vai ver opções para namespaces, pacotes de desenvolvimento e tipos de proxy (consumer ou provider). Escolha "Consumer Proxy" se for consumir a API. Aqui, o PI entra em jogo: configure o adapter no Integration Directory para mapear os campos.

  3. Implementar a Lógica no ABAP: Na SE38, SE80 ou Eclipse, acesse a classe gerada. Crie um método para chamar o proxy, passando parâmetros como autenticação (básica ou OAuth).  Exemplo de código simples:


Teste com o debugger para ver se os dados fluem corretamente.

  1. Configurar no PI/PO: No Integration Builder, crie um cenário com o proxy como sender/receiver. Use adapters como SOAP ou HTTP para conectar à API. Monitore via PIMON para logs e erros.

  2. Testes e Troubleshooting: Sempre teste com ferramentas como Postman antes de implementar. Problemas comuns? Certificados inválidos ou timeouts – verifique o SOAMANAGER para configurações de endpoint.



Onde tem a Interface de Serviço, vai aparecer duas Inboud e Outboud (clique com o botão direito do mouse na qual deseja criar o proxy), após isso, é só ativar que o SAP vai gerar todos os objetos.

Vantagens e Desafios no Mundo Real

Nas implantações que fiz aqui na Bahia, com empresas locais de varejo e manufatura, o SPROXY salvou horas de desenvolvimento. Vantagens: integração nativa com ABAP, suporte a transações assíncronas e escalabilidade via PI. Mas desafios existem – como lidar com APIs REST puras (o SPROXY é mais SOAP-oriented, então use adapters para converter).

Se você está migrando para nuvem, fique de olho: isso é base para entender evoluções como o SAP BTP e Integration Suite, que modernizam tudo com low-code. (Falando nisso, em um próximo post, vou correlacionar isso com as novas integrações no BTP – fiquem ligados!)

Conclusão e Chamada para Ação

Integrações via SPROXY em ABAP/PI são robustas e essenciais para quem ainda lida com on-premise, mas preparam o terreno para o futuro híbrido. O que vocês acham? Já usaram SPROXY em projetos? Compartilhem nos comentários, e vamos trocar figurinhas na comunidade SAP da Bahia. Se precisar de mais detalhes, me mandem DM!

Segue abaixo um passo a passo simples:

#SAP #ABAP #PI #Integrações #APIs #SPROXY #ComunidadeSAPBahia

entry.title: Activate Joule Studio in 5 Simple Steps
entry.content:
Joule Studio is a capability in SAP Build that allows organizations to create and deploy custom Joule agents and skills that automate workflows and improve efficiency across SAP and non-SAP systems. Currently the Agent Builder offering is in Beta and the Skill Builder  offering is generally available. In this blog, we will focus on activation of the Skill Builder in Joule which is now Generally Available.

The key pre-requisites to activate Skill Builder with Joule Studio are as follows:-

  • Access to BTP Global Account with the following entitlements available via Subscription, BTPEA, CPEA or PAYG model:
    • SAP Build Process Automation, build-default (Application) plan
    • Joule, foundation (Application)/ standard (Application) plan
  • SAP Cloud Identity Services- Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning instance is activated 

Read more about the service and pre-requisites in these following blogs from our product leaders and managers:

  • Joule Studio is generally available in SAP Build: Empower your business with intelligent automation
  • Build, Deploy, and Extend AI Agents with Joule Studio
  • How to Get Started with Joule Studio

Activating Joule Studio - Skill Builder in 5 Simple Steps

Here is a quick hit video capturing the steps documented below:

 

Step 1 - Create a BTP Subaccount and Assign the Entitlements:

Create a subaccount in your BTP Global Account and select region where both Joule, foundation/ standard and Build Process Automation, build-default plans are available. Find the list of regions supported for Joule service at this SAP Help Portal link and Build Process Automation Service at this SAP Help Portal link.

  • Click on Create button on BTP Global Account landing page and select Subaccount option

  • Enter the relevant details including selecting the suitable region and click on Create button

Enable Cloud Foundry Environment

  • Click on Enable Cloud Foundry button on the subaccount landing page

  • Update the details in the window and click on Create button

Create Space in the Cloud Foundry Environment

  • Select the Create Space button that appears after the Cloud Foundry Environment is created

  • Select the relevant roles and click on the Create button

Add Joule and  Build Process Automation entitlements

  • Navigate to Entitlements section from subaccount landing page
  • Click on Edit button

  • Select Add Service Plans button

 

  • Search for Joule in the search bar and select the foundation (Application) plan of the Joule service 

  • Next, search for build process in the search bar and select the build-default (Application) plan from SAP Build Process Automation service
  • Click on  Add 2 Service Plans button to add the entitlements to the relevant subaccount

  • Click on Save button on the Entitlements page

Step 2- Complete Trust Configuration and Activate Build Process Automation (Subaccount):

Create a Trust Configuration to add authentication for application users in the IAS tenant on BTP

  • Navigate to Security > Trust Configuration section under your BTP subaccount
  • Click on Establish Trust button

  • Select the suitable IAS tenant and click on Next button

  • Choose the domain consistent with your BTP account and non-BTP applications and click on the Next button

  • Review and update the relevant parameters in this screen and click on Next button

  • Review the details and click on Finish button

Enable the Build Process Automation Service, build-default plan

  • Navigate to Instances and Subscriptions section under your BTP subaccount and click on Create button

  • Select the SAP Build Process Automation service and build-default plan and click on Create button

  • The service will be created as seen under Subscriptions

Step 3 - Run Joule Booster to Activate Joule Studio Capability Package (Global Account):

Activate Joule Studio Capability Package on SAP Build Process Automation

  • Navigate to your BTP Global Account and select the Boosters section
    • Search for Joule in the search bar and select the Setting Up Joule booster tile

  • Click on Start button

  • After the prerequisites are checked and required entitlements are met, click on Next button 

  • Select the Joule (das-application) plan and the subaccount where Build Process Automation service is activated and click on Next button

  • After selecting the products to be integrated on the following screen and selecting relevant system type option click on Next button. Review Integrating Joule with SAP Solutions help document for more details on pre-requisites for integration with the relevant SAP systems in your organization

  • Select the SAP Build Process Automation option from the Capability Packages dropdown, click on Next button

  • Review the Formation Name and select the correct service instance number - URL from the SAP Build Process Automation System dropdown then click on the Next button

  • Review the details on the final page of the booster and click on Finish button

  • After processing, the Success window appears, click on the Close button after reviewing status

Step 4 - Create Role Collection and Assign Users (Subaccount):

Create Role Collection and assign the role collection the relevant users

  • Navigate to the Subaccount where the Build Process Automation service is installed and navigate to the Role Collections section and click on Create button; Enter the relevant details and click on Create button

  • Select the recently created role collection line item from the list and click on Edit button

  • Select search help option in first empty line item under Roles

  • Enter the search text "das" Application Identifier dropdown, select the right option from the list and select the end_user and extensibility_developer roles from the list below. Click on Add button after selecting the roles

  • Click the Save button for the role collection we created

  • Navigate to Users option under the Security section of the subaccount and click Create button

  • Select the Identity Provider for which the trust configuration was added, add the user details and click on Create button

  • Click on the new user created in the table, navigate to Role Collections section, click on the options(...) and select Assign Role Collections option

  • Select the role collection created in the previous step from the list along with any other relevant roles and click on the Assign Role Collection button

  • Navigate to Instances and Subscriptions and select the SAP Build Process Automation instance

  • Click on Create after the Build Lobby loads

  • The Joule Skill option should now be available for you to create custom Joule Skills

Step 5 - Build Your First Custom Joule Skill:

Follow the Build custom Joule skills for SAP and non-SAP systems using Joule Studio mission to get started with building your custom skills on Joule Studio.

Congratulations, you are all set to start building Custom Skills with the Skill Builder on Joule Studio!

Please do leave kudos and comments as feedback to help us keep improving the quality of our content.

Additional Resources 

Architecture Overview

Joule Skill Demo Video

Smart Advisory Companion – Inspiration Video

🧭 Product Tour

FAQ

entry.title: Re: ME22N screen line item 20 conditions cannot be seen s...
entry.content:
The error “Net price must be greater than 0” in ME22N usually occurs because the system is not picking up valid condition records (PB00, PBXX, etc.) or because pricing determination is incomplete. It is not caused by the screen alignment issue you mentioned

Below are some of the possible root causes

  • If PB00/PBXX or other pricing condition types are not maintained in the system, the PO line item cannot calculate a net price.
  • The pricing schema assigned to your vendor/purchase org may not be triggering the expected condition types.
  • In some cases, if account assignment or order unit is missing, the system resets the net price field, leading to the error

To fix this, perform the below steps

  • Go to transaction MEK3 or MEK2 and verify that PB00/PBXX records exist for the vendor, material, and purchasing org. If missing, maintain them in MEK1.
  • Verify Pricing Schema and ensure the schema assigned to your vendor/purchasing org includes PB00/PBXX.
  • In the PO line item, go to Conditions tab → choose Update (Carry out new pricing). This forces the system to re-pull condition records.

entry.title: Re: Task List Operation linked with Functional location
entry.content:
Hi 

If the functional location (FL) is assigned to the task list operation and you expect this FL to flow into the operations of the maintenance order generated from the maintenance plan, here are the key steps and checks that will enable the behavior:

Ensure Task List Header vs. Operation Assignment

If you assigned the FL only to the task list header, the operations may not pick it up.

Better to assign the FL at the operation level of the task list (in IA05/IA06 or via the task list change transaction).

When you generate the order, the system will copy the operation-level object reference into the order operations.

Check the Maintenance Plan Scheduling Settings

In the maintenance plan (IP02/IP10), under “Call Object”, ensure that the task list is used and that the plan is defined so the header and operations will adopt the object reference (FL or equipment).

Important: In the maintenance plan header maintain the technical object field as well. If both FL and equipment are blank there, the order will not carry it.

Check the Order Type Settings for Object Reference Transfer

In SPRO → Maintenance and Service Processing → Maintenance and Service Orders → Functions and Settings for Order Types → “Define Order Type” (OIS2)

Ensure the order type has the checkboxes “Copy object list” or “Supplied object reference” enabled. This allows object reference (FL/Equipment) to be copied from the plan to the order.

Task List Usage and Strategy

Make sure the task list version you used is active and your maintenance plan uses the correct version.

In case the object reference is dynamically supplied, check if Strategy allows “dynamic object assignment”. For static FL reference, the FL must be entered in the task list.

Order Monitoring and Verification

After generating the order (via IP10 or automatic call), open the order (IW31/IW32) → Go to “Operations” tab → In each operation check the “Technical Object” column where the FL should appear.

If still blank, test by manually creating an order using the same task list to check if the FL flows.

entry.title: Re: SAP PM. Issue in IW32 – Adding Components via Structu...
entry.content:
Hi  charllotte ;

You can easily display and edit the Component Quantity field in your maintenance order.
Here’s how you can do it step-by-step in IW31 / IW32:

Go to 
Transaction IW31 or IW32 and open your order.

Navigate to the Components tab.

Make sure the equipment or functional location you’re using has a BOM (created in IB01 / IB02).
When you press the List button in the Components tab, the structure list from the BOM will appear.

Now, go to the top menu bar and choose:
Settings → Field Selection → Component.

In the pop-up window that appears, scroll on the right-hand side and look for the fields:

Comp. Qty (CUn)

Component Quantity

Move these fields to the upper section (Visible area) using the arrow buttons.
This will make the quantity column visible next to your material number in the component overview screen.

After saving this layout, you’ll always see and can adjust the Component Quantity directly in the Components tab.

Hope this helps!
Best regards,
Ali Zamani
Senior SAP PM Consultant

entry.title: Re: Resource not available message in Work Order
entry.content:
Hi JAYA0511 ;

When you assign a personal number in the Person Responsible field in the header of a maintenance work order in SAP S/4HANA (PM module), and you get the message “Resource is not available”, the root causes and configurations to check are:

Resource / Personnel Master Data Availability

The person you entered must exist as a resource or personnel record in SAP with correct availability. If the system treats the partner or resource as a “personnel” but cannot find an active assignment or availability for that person, then “Resource is not available” may appear.

Ensure the employee is represented in HR or as a Business Partner and linked to a work centre or scheduling node if you use scheduling.

For personnel resources, ensure the “Workforce / Resource” setup is done and the resource is marked as available. See KBA 2979880 – Search Help for ‘Person Responsible’ field.

Work Centre or Capacity/Resource Scheduling Check

If the work order uses capacity planning or resource scheduling (e.g., via SAP Multiresource Scheduling), the system checks if the assigned resource is free on the scheduled date/time. If the resource is already allocated, on leave, or not assigned to a valid work centre, the system may block with “Resource is not available”.

SAP documentation states that during order release the system checks materials, production resources and tools.

Partner Function vs. Planning Function

The “Person Responsible” in a work order header is a partner assignment, but not automatically treated as the operational resource unless you also assign the work centre or resource in the operations. If you only fill the partner field but operations belong to a work centre without linking the person, the system may interpret the resource as not available (because the scheduled operations still rely on the work centre resource).

Check if the partner function used (for example AUFTR) is intended for resource assignment or just for responsibility reporting.

Missing Configuration for Manual Assignment

In Customizing (SPRO) under Maintenance and Service Orders → Functions and Settings for Order Types → Scheduling / Capacity / Resource Planning, review whether the order type allows manual resource assignment or checks resource availability. If the setting “Check capacities during release” is active, assignment of unavailable resource triggers the error.

entry.title: Re: Missing description in Key combination window in tran...
entry.content:
The missing descriptions in NACR when logged in with English are due to untranslated key combination texts (condition table descriptions). These are stored in customizing and can be translated using transaction SE63 (Translation Environment) or by maintaining the text entries in SPRO → Output Control → Condition Tables. In short: you need to translate the condition table descriptions (and possibly field catalog texts) into English.

In NACR, after selecting an application and output type, the system shows the key combinations (condition tables) available for maintaining condition records. Each key combination has a short description stored in the system. In your system, the German texts exist, but the English translations are missing, so when you log in with English, the nodes appear blank. This is not an ECC vs. S/4 issue—it’s simply a matter of missing translations in your customizing layer.

So with the above explanations, the fix is log in with English and open NACR. Note which nodes are blank. Identify the condition table numbers behind those nodes (you can see them in the technical view or via debugging). Go to SE63 and maintain the English translation for those tables. Save and transport the translations if needed.

entry.title: Re: Statistical Delivery Date Report in SAP S4 HANA
entry.content: There is no standard report in SAP ECC or S/4HANA, that directly compares Statistical Delivery Date vs. Delivery Date for all POs. However, you can get this information by using standard purchasing reports (ME2N/ME2M/ME2L/ME2K) with ALV layout changes, or by building a custom query (SQVI/SE16N) on tables like EKPO for PO items and EKET for schedule lines. To include the GR date, you need to join with MATDOC for material document or EKBE for PO history.

entry.title: Sydney Stammtisch Recap Oct '25
entry.content:
It couldn't rain for the 3rd ##SAPStammtischSYD in a row could it?  No, it couldn't!  We actually had a pretty nice day for it and the roof at The Paragon stayed wide open

As always, it was a real joy to see brand new faces joining us.  A joy too to see some unexpected reunions happen

As you can see from the photos we trialed a new system to make it easier for newcomers to get to know everyone: Stickers and a felt pen to write your name. Judging by the blank stickers left we had about 37 or 38 attendees. I think we should make this a regular thing

Thanks so much to everyone who came along to an event this year.  We are thrilled with the great attendance but would dearly love to improve the gender balance.  Please do let us know if you have any suggestions as to how we can assist with that

See you next year!  Get in touch (or leave a comment) if you have suggestions as to where we should be meeting and even whether we should try out a different night of the week
